name: NewYorker
text:
A piece by Jelani Cobb, from 2017.
https://t.co/6WgmAZswe5

name: NewYorker
text: On our latest podcast, Peter Hessler reports from Chengdu, China, on what life after lockdown looks like, and why the experience in the U.S. will be very different. Listen here. https://t.co/ygEqpKTeRc

name: NewYorker
text:
“So scary are the consequences of a collapse of white privilege that many Americans have flocked to a political platform that supports and translates violence against the defenseless as strength,” Toni Morrison wrote, in 2016.
https://t.co/iTgasxH70C

name: NewYorker
text:
Robin DiAngelo’s 2018 book “White Fragility” argues that our segregated society is set up to insulate whites from racial discomfort, so that they fall to pieces at the first application of stress.
https://t.co/KGBXOL4jW0

name: NewYorker
text: CNN has spoken out on behalf of Omar Jimenez, but we would be remiss not to interrogate how it has wrung the injustice that its reporter experienced for high-drama TV, @dstfelix writes. https://t.co/eHeEoNRSfa

name: NewYorker
text: “When I have my camera on me, I don’t forget that I’m a black human being,” the photographer Chris Facey said. “I remember why I’m at these protests.” https://t.co/9LSctNWvXs

name: NewYorker
text:
On our latest podcast, @xwaldie picks three novels to bring humor to dark times. Listen here, or wherever you get your podcasts.
https://t.co/x45kVYMWJK

name: NewYorker
text: A new video shows New York City's eerily empty landscape, with commentary from front-line medical personnel and essential workers whose work continues, off camera. https://t.co/uCm3h8j1cI

name: NewYorker
text: The German pianist Igor Levit is used to playing carefully chosen programs at concert halls all over the world. At home, he can choose whatever pieces ﬁt his mood. https://t.co/6t3J2BXJoo

name: NewYorker
text: Facebook has never been a neutral platform—it is a company whose business model depends on monitoring its users, modifying and manipulating their behavior, and selling their attention to the highest bidder. https://t.co/mWdbMunJxa

name: NewYorker
text: How should a society respond to a looming crisis of uncertain timing but of catastrophic proportions? #NewYorkerArchive https://t.co/iqPpuTtdst

name: NewYorker
text:
The coronavirus crisis is not an unpredictable, rare catastrophe, according to Nassim Nicholas Taleb. He, like Bill Gates, Laurie Garrett, and others, predicted it earlier this year.
https://t.co/PqZTz2xG6Y

name: NewYorker
text: “I’ve always been able to provide for me and my daughter,” said the owner of a chain of child-care centers around Philadelphia. “Now I’ve just applied for food stamps for the first time in my life.” https://t.co/5vxwK8ciQr

name: NewYorker
text: Arif Husain, of the World Food Programme, describes how the coronavirus pandemic will worsen hunger and food insecurity around the world. https://t.co/txKeY95iV0

name: NewYorker
text: Our Memorial Day sale is here. Save 50% and get a free, limited-edition tote. https://t.co/mvnyRshbTg https://t.co/wOxozlZGba

name: NewYorker
text: When employees at a grocery-store chain in Oregon wear masks during their shifts, shoppers remark that they’re "feeding hysteria," and say "there’s nothing going on and it’s a government thing,” one check-out worker said. https://t.co/FjX0H14ZgX

name: NewYorker
text: For the next 20 hours, the pianist Igor Levit will perform Erik Satie’s “Vexations” to raise awareness of the plight of artists worldwide. Watch live. https://t.co/0YOr36WwkA

name: NewYorker
text: New discoveries about the human mind show the limitations of reason. https://t.co/uXVixGExZP

name: NewYorker
text: The coronavirus crisis and the protests following George Floyd’s death are not unrelated; they’re bound by their predictability and by the ways in which the Trump Administration has exacerbated them. https://t.co/Kt4BuGVNmF

name: NewYorker
text: In a piece from 1996, Arthur Miller shares the story behind his drama about the Salem witch trials. #NewYorkerArchive https://t.co/SNB7VKtE9q

name: NewYorker
text:
Astoria's Bel Aire Diner has been open all 24 hours of every single day since it was purchased, in 1996, Now it survives the pandemic by hosting drive-in movies in the parking lot.
https://t.co/T8HNHGLlQF

name: NewYorker
text: How the sociologist Howard Becker studies the conventions of the unconventional. https://t.co/ejtyS5FUAL

name: NewYorker
text: “What I found from the 1960s is that nonviolent protest achieved many of the same sorts of outcomes that the more militant activists were fighting for without splintering the Democratic coalition.” An interview with @owasow. https://t.co/9MLItzYSOs
